title: Luce Center Scavenger Hunts
welcome: Welcome to Scavenger Hunts at the Smithsonian American Art Museum
about:
Complete the Luce Center scavenger hunts to test your skills! Bring one of the hunts to the Luce Foundation Center and follow the clues to find specific artworks among the more than 3,000 objects on display.

Get all of the answers correct and win a prize!

hunts.title: Women's History Month Scavenger Hunt
hunts.description: Explore famous women in our collection!
hunts.instructions: Follow the clues around the Luce Foundation Center to find these pieces by female artists. Answer the questions and bring your completed hunt back to the Luce Center info desk to claim your prize!

tasks.title: Find Helen Cordero
tasks.instructions: Begin your hunt in the Folk Art section and find this singer. Helen Cordero is a potter from the Cochiti Pueblo in New Mexico. Cordero is credited with creating these “storyteller” figures.

location.name: Luce Foundation Center, Folk Art section

question.hint: The accession number is listed on the card.

tasks.title: What year was "Christmas"?
tasks.instructions: Stay in Folk Art and find this painting of a winter scene. The work of this popular artist has been featured on greeting cards and other merchandise.

question.hint: The painter was known as Grandma Moses.

solution.correct: Nice! That was a hard one.

tasks.title: Find this sculpture
tasks.instructions: Walk over to the Sculpture section to find this piece by Edmonia Lewis, the first professional African American sculptor to achieve international recognition. This sculpture of Moses is a copy after the piece by Michelangelo.

question.text: Check the box when you've found this sculpture.

tasks.title: Flower
tasks.instructions: Go upstairs and find this image by an artist known for her paintings of large flowers.

question.text: What kind of flower is this?
question.hint: The artist's name is Georgia O'Keeffe.

solution.correct: Good job! Are you a botanist?

tasks.title: Red Abstraction
tasks.instructions: Find this work by Alma Thomas, an expressionist painter from Washington, D.C. The artist attended Howard University and later taught art to junior high school students.

location.name: Luce Foundation Center, Folk Art section

question.text: How does this painting make you feel?
question.hint: As Whoopi Goldberg once said "Art and life are subjective. Not everybody's gonna dig what I dig, but I reserve the right to dig it."
